Literature Review: The intricate relationship between culture and personality has long been a subject of interest within the field of psychology. This literature review aims to explore the roots, trends, and interplay of culture and personality through the lens of the Socioecological-Genetic Framework, integrating recent advancements in socioecology and genetics. The framework posits that individuals are both influenced by and influencers of culture, highlighting a dynamic interplay that has been underexplored in previous research. The roots of culture and personality can be traced back to the mutual constitution of these constructs, where socioecological factors and genetic predispositions play pivotal roles. Socioecological changes, such as urbanization and technological advancements, have been shown to influence temporal trends in culture and personality, suggesting a fluidity that adapts to environmental shifts. Furthermore, the interaction between genes and culture/socioecology (nature Ã— nurture interactions) offers a nuanced understanding of personality development, emphasizing the importance of considering both genetic and environmental factors. This integrative approach not only bridges the gap between the literatures on culture and personality but also provides a comprehensive framework for future research. By spotlighting the roles of socioecology and genetics, the Socioecological-Genetic Framework advances our understanding of the complex dynamics between culture and personality, offering insights into their roots, trends, and interplay.
